title: Wednesday, 9th March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

Maybe start off on a serious note for a change

PM

This is something from yesterday, but I didn't get it written up until late, so most of you will not have seen it

11:01 am
PM

PM

You can read this supposedly secret document here: http://ftalphavill...MMERCE-WEBSITE.pdf

PM

It's not secret now cos the US Commerce department put it up on their website

11:02 am
PM

It concerns action against ZTE, -- HUGE chinese telecoms equipment maker

PM

I think this story is being seriously underplayed

PM

That doc -- in pretty clean english -- sets out the ZTE plan to evade US sanctions against Iran

11:03 am
PM

And the Americans have responded by simply blowing ZTE up

PM

Banned all exports to ZTE -- including all foreigners exporting anything that has an American component in it

PM

This is serious trade war stuff

11:04 am
PM

And the US is putting what looks like its secret service behind it

PM

There's irony here of course

PM

Everyone gets outraged at the idea of Chinese companies spying on Western firms

11:05 am
PM

While the US government openly spies on Chinese companies -- and is happy to show the evidence

PM

Click the link above

PM

It's the equivalent of corporate drone warfar

11:05 am
PM

e

PM

And ZTE found itself on the kill list

PM

I won't go on

11:05 am
PM

But im convinced this is a HUGE deal

PM

Lots and lots of knock on effects

PM

All suppliers to ZTE, globally hit hard

11:06 am
PM

Actually, came across a US expert on SINO/US trade stuff yesterday

PM

Bill Petty

PM

And his newsletter has landed overnight

11:07 am
PM

Let me get an extract

PM

Having looked at the internal confidential ZTE report, which Commerce in a very unusual situation has published as a public document on its website, ZTE truly has been caught red handed. The ZTE Report lays out a detailed scheme to evade US Export Control laws. No country, including the United States or China, would tolerate such a scheme to systematically evade a country’s laws.

PM

From the Chinese point of view, however, the Commerce Department has no credibility because its antidumping laws presently block about $30 billion in imports based on fake numbers. Because the US Government’s Import and Export Control Administration are both located in the Commerce Department, the Chinese government looks at all the Department’s decisions as US based protectionism.

The problem is that through its nonmarket economy methodology, which does not use actual costs and prices to determine dumping, Commerce has created a game, and the Chinese will play it. Sometimes Chinese companies talk to me about using the “houmen” back door and shipping products through different countries to evade US antidumping laws. I always tell the Chinese companies that this is Customs fraud and they risk civil and criminal prosecution under US Customs and trade laws.

In fact, in the past Chinese honey suppliers that used transshipment to get around the US antidumping law were caught in the United States and hauled in front of Federal Court on criminal charges for evasion of US antidumping laws. I have heard of one Chinese company seafood executive arrested in Belgium and sent to Belgian jail on an extradition warrant for evasion of US antidumping laws.

With the enactment of the New Trade and Customs Enforcement Act, described above, the US government now has more ways of catching Chinese companies and US importers that try to evade US trade laws. As one Chinese friend told me, such actions are “too damned dangerous”.

11:07 am
PM

Although US judgments are not enforceable in China, Chinese companies have to also realize, that like ZTE, they have grown up and have subsidiaries all around the World. US judgments may not be enforceable in China, but they are enforceable in Hong Kong and other countries, and every Chinese company I have ever dealt with has a Hong Kong bank account. Through its scheme to evade US export control laws, ZTE now has major problems and those problems may now multiply worldwide.

PM

Here's Bill's blog http://uschinatradewar.com/

And when HSBC tripped over the 5% disclosure limit, it was the reporting aggregate stake size.

BE

I thought there was a limit to how much value one might extract by stating the obvious.

11:13 am
BE

Seems not though. Here's the Bloomberg story.

BE

(Bloomberg) -- HSBC Holdings Plc’s disclosure that it held 5 percent of Burberry Group Plc’s shares was part of a series of trades rather than a single bidder building a stake in the U.K. fashion retailer, according to people familiar with the matter.

BE

Yep. Don't think anyone's claimed otherwise.

11:13 am
BE

To do so would be to imply that HSBC's not an investment manager. Which'd be baffling.

BE

HSBC triggered the regulatory disclosure last month after executing trades for a number of parties that briefly took its aggregated holdings above the 5 percent threshold, said the people, who asked not to be identified as the matter is private.

BE

Actually, the matter isn't private. Shareholdings are a matter of public record.

11:13 am
BE

The Companies Act 2006 is very clear.

BE

Burberry hasn’t received any takeover approach, the people said.

BE

Again, not news.

11:14 am
BE

BE

Tricky stuff, this anonymous sourcing.

BE

One misstep and and you can throw a feltcollaredsource under a bus.

11:14 am
BE

Now, perhaps what Bloomberg could've done here is to check its own data.

BE

Which shows that HSBC's ultimate aggregate position went from 606,173 shares in Q4 2015 to 11,855,289 shares in Q1 2016.

BE

An increase of 11,249,116 shares.

11:15 am

11:34 am
BE

Instead, here's Barclays.

BE

FY15 results are in line, but current trading is poor. EBIT was +10.5% to £88.9m vs Barclays £89.5m, Bloomberg consensus £88.8m. EBIT margins were 13.0%, +30bps against FY14 vs. +10bps in H1, within which wage cost inflation and central overheads were offset by minimal food price inflation. EPS was +12.8% to 33.8p vs Barclays 33.5p, consensus 33.4p. DPS +13% to 17.4p vs. Barclays estimates of 16.9p. 44 new sites were opened in FY15 (gross), as stated in the post-close update in January. Despite a solid FY15, current trading LFLs are negative. LFLs are -1.5% for the first 10 weeks of FY15. This compares with LFLs of +1.5% for FY15, albeit this weakened significantly in the latter months of the year. We estimate LFLs turned negative in the final 7 weeks months of FY15 fell to -1.7%. The company cited specific factors for this in their pre-close statement (eg, increase in online Christmas shopping, flooding), but trading remains poor. We estimate cumulative weekend cinema box office revenues are weak rather than disastrous -1.6% to the 28th Feb but admissions – ie footfall, will be worse than this due to ticket price inflation. Conversely, we believe that the concessions business (c20% of EBITDA) will be performing strongly given solid passenger numbers. Given the relative resilience of pub LFLs in recent announcements, we believe that oversupply of branded restaurants is continuing to hit LFLs, and as such see no easing in trading conditions until there is a slowdown in the pace of rollout, or even casualties in this space. Comps for the first 8 weeks of FY15 were +2.5%. From a cost perspective, food price inflation looks benign in FY16, and the same is true for energy costs, but these benefits will be offset by wage pressure (£2m guided hit from National Living Wage increase, similar to previous guidance). We believe the shares will react negatively to this statement. Valuation based on current estimates: FY16 PE rating of 14.3x, EV/EBITDA 7.6x, FCF yield (pre exp capex) 9.2%, dividend yield 3.5%.

BE

Singer goes back to sell.

BE

The FY15 outcome is in-line with previously reduced expectations. So in summary PBT rose by 11.2% to £86.8m, with LFL
growth of 1.5%. This fed through to 12.8% EPS growth to 33.8p and EBIT margin was +30bps. The main positive surprise
was on the net-debt side of things which came in at £29.2m vs our £39.6m.
Divisionally we note positive commentary around Chiquito, Coast to Coast, Pub Restaurants and Concessions.
However, the top-brand, Frankie & Bennny’s had a more challenging year it seems, with increased competition cited
as one of the drag features of the year. In FY15 44 new units were added to the overall group portfolio and a broadly
similar number is targeted for FY16, albeit we fear there is risk on the downside here.
The main talking point this morning is the weak start to FY16 with LFL’s -1.5% after 10 weeks vs a c.2.5% comp. This is
below expectations and we fundamentally believe this reflects strong competitive headwinds/over supply – as outlined
in our large sector note recently. We accept there may be some cannibalisation of RTN sites as a factor also.
Management put the slow start down to faltering UK consumer demand, but judging by recent updates from Greggs,
Revolution Bars and Domino’s, we would argue that over supply in the casual dining sector is the key factor.

11:37 am
BE

With management effectively guiding to flat LFL’s this morning and given the ST NLW headwind, we see 3-4% downside risk to current year forecasts and greater than 5% for FY17 and FY18. We move back to Sell with a reduced 12m TP of 450p – effectively 13.5x FY16 earnings.

BE

And Panmure.

BE

Although FY15 results came in slightly ahead of expectations (PBT £86.8m vs
PGe £86.3m) the bounce-back in current trading failed to materialise leading us
to take a more cautious stance on LFL growth going forward. Hence we are
cutting our 2016E forecasts by 4.5% and reducing our price target by 15% to
640p (from 750p) equivalent to 9.50x 2016E EV/EBITDA – in line with the sector.
Newly opened sites are performing well but the retail park locations are
suffering from lower footfall and in some cases up against refurbished
competition. We no longer believe that this is temporary (weather, post Paris)
but more macro-driven and expect the various business trackers to also turn
negative in due course. Although we believe that the shares offer good value at
these levels, we recognise that they will struggle to gain traction in a 0% LFL
Sales growth environment and hence move to Hold.
 FY15 Results. The Restaurant Group announced FY15 results with Sales +7.0% to
£685m (PGe £689.7m), EBIT +9.4% to £88.9m (PGe £88.5m), Underlying PBT +11.2%
£86.8m (PGe £86.3m), EPS up +12.8% to 33.8p (PGe 33.3p) with DPS increase 13% to
17.4p (PGe 16.6p). Net debt fell to £28.4m with FCF generation still strong. However
trading into the new financial year has yet to recover with LFL in the first 10 weeks of
the year running -1.5% compared to -1.7% recorded over the last 7 weeks of 2015 -
less than +1.0% we were expecting. Although this is a quiet time of the year and is up
against some strong comparatives it is nonetheless disappointing. We had originally
concluded (wrongly) that this was temporary but now believe it is due to macro shifts
alongside industry specific supply issues.

Just Eat was the fourteenth best performer in the FTSE 250 Company in 2015. By qualifying as a top quintile performance, management would have achieved the maximum stock compensation award. This appears to be behind the announcement this morning of the CEO/CFO being awarded 235k/129k shares respectively. At the current run rate for this year they wouldn't be getting the reward as the company is in the bottom decile of the FTSE 250 performance YTD 2016. Perhaps this incentive scheme explains why the management seem somewhat obsessed with the stock price and focus heavily on positive PR? We would rather the company focused on core operations and a worrying trend we see in user satisfaction. From our investigations we are increasingly concerned about the raft of negative reviews of the Just Eat service. Just look at the comments on the pinned post on Just Eat's UK Facebook page for example. 95% are negative and many vitriolic.

The Amazon Flex model is perfectly primed for such an assault. We continue to see structural risk and margin compression risk for Just Eat. As such, we remain sellers.

11:48 am
BE

Jefferies' downgrade of Billiton is typical.

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 814.80, down 6.6 (-0.80%), High: 832.80, Low: 809.80, Volume: 3.98m
BE

Even after yesterday's carnage, BHP's share price is above our target as
commodity prices have been stronger than expected, sentiment regarding
mining has improved, and shorts have covered. While the Chinese demand
outlook may be slightly better than it was two months ago and more metalsintensive
stimulus may be coming, our analysis indicates that most commodity
prices will go lower in the near term. We downgrade to Hold.

11:48 am
BE

BHP's mark-to-market valuation is reasonable: The mining sector is coming off its
biggest six week rally in 30+ years, with the FTSE Mining Index up 70% from Jan 20-Mar
7 versus the FTSE All-Share Index up 9% over that period. Commodity prices have also
significantly increased, with iron ore up 46%, oil up 9%, and copper up 6% YTD (iron ore,
oil and copper account for more than 90% of BHP's NPV, on our estimates). At current spot
commodity prices, BHP is on a FY16E FCF yield of 5.9% and EV/EBITDA of 6.4x and a FY17E
FCF yield of 11.1% and EV/EBITDA of 5.2x. If we assume a 50% payout ratio (consistent with guidance), BHP's FY17E dividend yield at spot would be 3.0%. Based on these valuations, we would buy BHP shares only if we were confident that the recent recovery in commodity prices is sustainable.

BE

Commodity prices to go lower: Based on our analysis, the recent strength in prices of
iron ore, copper and other mined commodities will at least partially reverse over the next
3-6 months. In the case of iron ore, supply growth from Roy Hill and a seasonal increase
in supply following what has been a period of typical weather-related supply disruptions
should pressure the price, especially if demand stays weak. We expect the iron ore price
to fall to below $40/t this summer (versus current spot of $64/t). In the case of copper, a
wave of supply growth (Cerro Verde, Las Bambas, Buenavista, Sentinel, Grasberg, Bozshakol, Antucoya and others) should more than offset any improvement in demand and lead to lower prices. Based on our commodity price forecasts rather than current, higher spot prices, BHP's valuation is stretched (FY16E FCF yield of 2.5% and EV/EBITDA of 8.1x and a FY17E FCF yield of 7.2% and EV/EBITDA of 6.9x, with an implied FY17E dividend yield of just 1.0%).

BE

BHP's strategy is a risk: In addition to a fairly expensive valuation (on our estimates)
and the likely negative momentum of lower commodity prices in the near term, there are
also still questions regarding BHP's recently announced strategic overhaul, which includes
major changes to divisional management and a regrouping of segments. There is also a
relatively high risk that BHP pursues M&A opportunities, especially in copper and possibly
conventional oil. An acquisition of a tier-1 copper asset would not be cheap (greater than 10x spot EBITDA), and the winner of what would likely be a bidding war would be at risk of
overpaying. We would prefer to see BHP use cash flow to pay down debt rather than
compete to buy high quality copper assets from the likes of Freeport or Glencore. All else
equal, we prefer sellers of good assets over buyers.

11:49 am
BE

Downgrading BHP shares after the recent rally: We have downgraded BHP shares
from Buy to Hold (but not changed our target prices) as we cannot identify likely near-term
positive catalysts, the company's strategy is still a risk, commodity prices should go lower
in the near-term following the recent strength, and BHP's valuation based on our estimates
is no longer inexpensive. BHP is well positioned for the long term, but the Buy case is not
evident for now.

BE

Shore. Solo Oil's house broker.

BE

Horse Hill flow testing update. Following on from the company’s recent announcements of excellent test results from the Horse Hill-1 well, Solo has announced that it has been informed by the operator that (during testing of the Upper Portland sandstone interval) good quality oil has flowed to surface via rod pumping from this zone at an average stabilised rate of 168bopd over a continuous nine hour period. Maximum flow was restricted by the initial rod pump configuration and the flow test will now continue with a pump configuration designed to permit optimal flow over a longer period. The Horse Hill-1 well continues to show excellent results from all horizons, having previously tested at rates of up to 900bopd from the Kimmeridge limestones. In our opinion, today’s update further validates the outstanding results achieved to date from this well. Ahead of final completion of testing of Horse Hill-1, and following the excellent results achieved to date, we expect development planning and commercial production to be clear objectives for the partners.

The Knight Frank Global House Price Index established in 2006 allows investors and developers
to monitor and compare the performance of mainstream residential markets around the world.
The index is compiled on a quarterly basis using official government statistics or central bank data
where available. The index’s overall performance is weighted by GDP on a Purchasing Power Parity
basis and the latest quarter’s data is provisional pending the release of all the countries’ results.
